@graph.name: Abusive
@graph.description: is compelled to use their utility surge to insult allies, increasing the test by +1 for the team.

@graph.name: Accelerate Spell
@graph.description: Increases the sorcery DC by 3 to Accelerate a spell for 1 AP. It can be used multiple times to reduce the sorcery time to up to half the original value. It is possible to accelerate spells to avoid opportunity attacks.

@graph.name: Acquiring a conviction
@graph.description: A character must adopt one worldview conviction and one instinct conviction during character creation. Each has a defined way of gaining XP through the character's actions.

@graph.name: Action Points (AP)
@graph.description: Action Points are a resource used to represent time. Actions cost AP to perform in situations where time is an important resource. The amount of AP each character receives at the beginning of each round is 6.

@graph.name: Action surge
@graph.description: All characters are entitled to one action surge per round. There are 3 basic types of action surges: movement, combat, and reaction.

@graph.name: Active encounter
@graph.description: It occurs against the group when they perform an exploration action in a node. It happens when the characters are being tracked, when there are patrols or predators in the area. It can occur with a luck roll.

@graph.name: Active test
@graph.description: Will can also be used actively by spending 3 AP to attempt to overcome fear, anger, confusion, and effects that attack will defense. They become free from the effects on a critical or success. The DL is the same as that which caused the effect.

@graph.name: Analyze Opponent
@graph.description: Cunning can also be used during a fight to assess an enemy. Spend 3 AP to make a cunning check against an enemy within 30m to try to obtain relevant information about them from visible equipment or physical characteristics. On a critical success, learn important information for combat, such as the creature's vulnerable areas, dangerous items they carry, or special abilities they may have. On a success, obtain a vague reference to a dangerous item or the opponent's power level. Grazes only provide obvious information, and failures provide nothing.

@graph.name: Anger
@graph.description: Receives -1 Mental and cannot make a reaction surge. The anger ends when the character succeeds on their Will check or becomes afraid.

@graph.name: Animal Encounters
@graph.description: Here are some ideas for animal encounters: a large fresh carcass is found, but it belongs to a predator. A nest full of eggs is discovered. A large animal is found sleeping in a grove. Something is chasing the group. Hundreds of birds are crossing the sky. A goat is on the edge of a cliff. A whole herd of bison is near the river. The river is full of alligators.

@graph.name: Armor Breakage
@graph.description: When armor breaks, it is considered pitted. Repairing armor costs 10

@graph.name: Armor coverage and Precision
@graph.description: Whenever an attack is a crit, it triggers the possibility of hitting an unprotected part of the body, having its PEN ignore armor toughness. To determine whether that happens, take all the overshoot of the attack's value over the crit threshold and add it to the weapon's precision bonus. If that value is greater than or equal to armor coverage, armor toughness is ignored.

@graph.name: Armorer
@graph.description: Knowledge of armoring and the appropriate equipment are necessary to repair weapons and armor. Repairing metal objects requires a forge.

@graph.name: Art - type
@graph.description: Knowledge about a specific form of art, for example, music, its greatest artists, and works.

@graph.name: Artisan
@graph.description: Any merchant who is not a contact charges +50

@graph.name: Attack against equipment
@graph.description: An attack can be made against a weapon, shield, or any object in order to break them. The deflection bonus is not added, and the impact is 150

@graph.name: Attack and Defend
@graph.description: Strike and defend can be used by the characters involved in the grapple against each other by using the grapple skill instead of strike and defend. Redirect can be used with 2 AP.

@graph.name: Avoiding an Explosion
@graph.description: Spend 2 AP and make a reflex skill test against the DL of the explosion. On a critical, the character can run by spending one extra STA. On a hit, they spend an extra STA to jump in any direction before the explosion occurs. On a graze or miss, they can move 2 AP after the explosion.

@graph.name: Ballista
@graph.description: the ballista is an oversized crossbow that needs a lever-based reloading system to be drawn by an average person. The power of its shots is comparable to that of a heavy bow.

@graph.name: Bardiche
@graph.description: is a large axe with a long blade at the tip. It has much in common with the battle axe, but it is used with two hands, which greatly increases its destructive potential. Additionally, the size of the blade allows it to deliver sweeping attacks, hitting multiple opponents at once. The bardiche does not have a good option for attacking opponents with high rigidity armor. These characteristics make it a relatively specialized weapon.

@graph.name: basic movement
@graph.description: Simple walking movement.

@graph.name: Battle Axe
@graph.description: It is a very good option against wooden objects or opponents with low-rigidity armor. Its blade combined with its weight makes it an excellent weapon for destroying shields. The axe is slower than swords, and its attacks can leave the user open to enemy offensives, so it is wise to make each attack count. Its defensive potential is low, as it is a shaft weapon. It is better to use the axe alongside a shield to compensate. The battle axe has a spike on the back, which is a better option against opponents whose armor the blade cannot penetrate.

@graph.name: Battlefield transformation
@graph.description: Trenches, hideouts, walls, traps.

@graph.name: Blind
@graph.description: -8 to vision.

@graph.name: Block
@graph.description: Costs 2 AP, but only shields can be used to block precise attacks. On a glancing blow or miss, it reduces the PEN by the TGH and the impact by the RES of the blocking object. The remainder is transferred to the character.

@graph.name: Braced
@graph.description: This attack can be a braced attack.

@graph.name: Braced Attack
@graph.description: A melee attack that attempts to increase strength by firmly bracing the weapon. It can be used as a reaction when a target is running towards the weapon or as an action in situations where the attacker is mounted. It costs an additional +2AP and +1STA on top of the normal attack cost and gives a -2 penalty to hit. The impact of this attack has a +STR bonus and knocks the opponent to the ground on hits if it is greater than 2x the target's natural RES. On a critical, it knocks down if impact > the target's natural RES.

@graph.name: Brass Knuckles
@graph.description: are a stronger version of the fists that are part of the armor. The character receives penalties for prestidigitation, accuracy, and climbing, but gains more coverage in the armor and has a much stronger and more resilient punch.

@graph.name: Brigandine
@graph.description: is made of rectangular metal plates sewn inside a fabric vest. Since the metal plates can slide over each other, the cost to mobility is not so high. It can be complemented with a closed helmet and gauntlets during a major battle, but it can also be used without the gauntlets to allow free use of ranged combat weapons. Most professional soldiers use this type of armor in their daily lives, as it has a high cost but is not prohibitive, and it is also not so heavy that activities like climbing hills or trees become impossible.

@graph.name: Burn, radiant, and corrosive damage
@graph.description: If the damage is greater than natural insulation + armor insulation, the target receives a light injury. If it is greater than 2x natural insulation + armor insulation, the target receives 2 light injuries, and so on.

@graph.name: Campfire
@graph.description: Characters must perform an exploration action to search for dry firewood and light the campfire. The action cannot be performed if there is no firewood or fuel. On a critical success, they do not spend the exploration action and succeed. On a success, they succeed. On a graze, they can either give up or spend double the time. On a failure, the action fails. The campfire allows cooking and provides +3 on the test against exposure.

@graph.name: Canceling Attack
@graph.description: It is possible to evade, dodge, or block while shooting, but the shot is canceled, and the costs of AP and STA are the greater of the defensive action or the shot.

@graph.name: careful movement
@graph.description: Slow movement used to improve stealth and balance.

@graph.name: Celebrating
@graph.description: It is possible to spend downtime improving popularity. The amount of money spent and the character's charisma determine how much reputation is gained.

@graph.name: Chain Shirt
@graph.description: is the only metallic armor among the light ones. Its value is somewhat higher than the others because the difficulty of production is greater. The chain shirt is worn over a greatcoat.

@graph.name: Changing attributes
@graph.description: It is possible to lose 1 point in one attribute to increase another, but this costs 2 XP.

@graph.name: Charged
@graph.description: can be charged into something and released when a trigger is activated. If the spell is not used within the duration of the charge, it dissipates.

@graph.name: Closed helmet
@graph.description: gives -3 to reflexes, -3 to cunning, and -3 to swimming, but hitting the head does not increase the severity of injuries. A closed helmet costs 15 GP or 15

@graph.name: Common clothing
@graph.description: is made of cotton or linen. It protects against very light injuries, such as bumping a shoulder against a rock or being scratched by a cat. Common people wear clothes of this type.

@graph.name: Compulsions
@graph.description: These are forced actions. They must occur immediately if there are enough AP. If not, they force action surges. If even that is not possible, the remaining AP are lost, and the compulsion ends. If the compulsion occurs during another character's action surge, it happens when the AP of the surge ends.

@graph.name: Conceal Objects
@graph.description: Used as a standard action of defense against detection tests to identify objects carried by the character. Successes detect and criticals identify the object. On grazes and failures, nothing is noticed.

@graph.name: Concentration
@graph.description: All sorcery tests require concentration. The only other action that can be performed while concentrating is careful movement. Being interrupted causes the loss of concentration. Sometimes, a character's AP may not be enough to cover the action's requirements. In that case, they can maintain concentration and continue acting in the next turn. Losing concentration causes all AP and STA spent to be lost. The character must interrupt concentration to be able to actively defend themselves.

@graph.name: Conceptual Map
@graph.description: The system was designed so that exploration actions could be performed on a conceptual map. Such a map consists of nodes. Each of them can have several events attached. The events can be accessible to characters by being present in the node and achieving good results in exploration tests.

@graph.name: Confused
@graph.description: Receives -3 Mental. Becomes vulnerable to domination attacks.

@graph.name: Consumption
@graph.description: Consumption is based on the number of troops.

@graph.name: Contacts
@graph.description: Having important contacts contributes to reputation.

@graph.name: Cooking
@graph.description: This test is made against the DL of the food and requires proper equipment for preparation. On a critical success, all food is utilized. On a success, only 75

@graph.name: Cover
@graph.description: A character can protect themselves against projectiles and explosion attacks by moving behind something, such as an ally or a wall. Staying behind something acts as a shield, reducing the damage taken by a certain amount. A character has cover if the shortest path from the origin of the explosion or projectile to a destination passes through a space containing a blocking object. Cover blocks vision unless it is transparent. Cover can be partial. In that case, it does not block vision and provides a bonus, usually +3, for reflexes and absorbs damage as if it were a shield in the case of grazes and misses.

@graph.name: Coward
@graph.description: is compelled to use their movement surge to run away and try to hide.

@graph.name: crawling
@graph.description: is the only usable movement speed while

@graph.name: Creative use of the system
@graph.description: This is an extra reward for finding new ways to be effective with your character using the system. Exploring weaknesses in enemies, winning a battle without taking damage, and resolving a violent situation diplomatically are examples of actions that can generate karma.

@graph.name: Crossbow
@graph.description: the crossbow is a weapon that can be fired quickly but requires reload time. The power of a crossbow shot is equivalent to that of a long bow.

@graph.name: Cunning
@graph.description: It is the ability to make good decisions quickly. It is the sum of detection and cunning skill. More details are in the combat section.

@graph.name: Dagger
@graph.description: are extremely versatile weapons. They can be used as tools or as weapons and are easily concealed. Daggers are also used as defensive tools, making them useful when held in the non-dominant hand.

@graph.name: Daily wear
@graph.description: The character receives 2 exhaustion, 2 hunger, and 2 thirst every day in addition to the wear generated by the exploration action. This can also be increased by the terrain.

@graph.name: Damage Multiplier (DM)
@graph.description: multiplies the HP of a character, the character's damage tolerances, and their armor, weapon damage, abilities, and spells.

@graph.name: Darkness and Night
@graph.description: In a situation of darkness, the field of vision is determined by the light source, having a good field of vision and a larger field of obscured vision. The rule works the same way if the light source is at a distance.

@graph.name: Dazzled
@graph.description: Receives -3 Vision.

@graph.name: DC
@graph.description: Difficulty / target metric (extracted as shorthand term)

@graph.name: Deadly
@graph.description: Ends when one team is neutralized.

@graph.name: Death
@graph.description: occurs when the character receives 3 deadly injuries or when a deadly injury has its severity increased.

@graph.name: DEF
@graph.description: Attacks that have DEF can be used to block.

@graph.name: Defeat Target
@graph.description: A specific target must be eliminated. One can flee after defeating the main target.

@graph.name: Defend
@graph.description: Ends when time runs out and the target is protected.

@graph.name: Degrees of success
@graph.description: Critical, hit, graze, and failure are the degrees of success. Critical is the best success, and failure is the worst failure. Regardless of the type of skill test, a score that exceeds a DL or defense by 10 or more is a critical success, 5 or more is a hit, 0 or more is a graze, and anything less than that is a failure.

@graph.name: Delay the turn
@graph.description: The player can spend 1 AP during their turn to delay it. This allows the character to regain their token and play again within the same round. AP regeneration only occurs once per round.

@graph.name: Delayed Spells
@graph.description: Any spell can be delayed, meaning that the casting can be completed, but the release is postponed. The character must concentrate on the spell until the release, which can be triggered by a previously prepared action. If a trigger does not occur, release it in the next turn.

@graph.name: Difficulty level (DL)
@graph.description: A level that defines how hard it is to overcome something. It is the number against which skill tests are made to determine the degree of success.

@graph.name: Disarm
@graph.description: A melee attack that attempts to disarm the opponent. This attack does not deal damage, but if it is a critical, it disarms the opponent with impact > natural RES. If it is a hit, it disarms with impact > 2x natural RES. Gains +0.5xSTR if the opponent attempts to block by redirecting.

@graph.name: Distance Measurement Recommendation
@graph.description: Measuring distance is a time-consuming process, so it is more practical to estimate the distance intuitively and give the benefit of the doubt in favor of the shooter.

@graph.name: Distance Penalties
@graph.description: If the target is 10m away or less, there is no penalty. Beyond that, a cumulative penalty of -2 to the attack is applied for every additional 10m of distance. From 50m onwards, the penalty is -2 for every additional 50m. The vertical range of a ranged weapon is half the horizontal range.

@graph.name: Distract
@graph.description: The goal is to capture the attention of one or more characters. It is an acting test against cunning. If done against a crowd, roll against the character who is hardest to distract.

@graph.name: Distracted
@graph.description: Receives -3 Mental. Occurs automatically when the character is in melee combat.

@graph.name: DL
@graph.description: Difficulty / target metric (extracted as shorthand term)

@graph.name: Dominated
@graph.description: Under the control of another character. Must obey commands for the duration but can make a Will check whenever the compulsion is severe. Outside of combat, can make a check once per hour.

@graph.name: Drag and Push
@graph.description: Grabbing someone enables the actions of dragging and pushing, which use strength as the skill.

@graph.name: Draw
@graph.description: Attack can be performed at the same time as drawing the weapon.

@graph.name: Efficient Spell
@graph.description: Increases the sorcery DC by 4 to reduce the exhaustion or STA cost of a spell by half.

@graph.name: Electric damage
@graph.description: Attacks the same defenses as burn damage, but receiving a serious injury from electric damage causes an interruption of 5 AP, and deadly damage leaves the target unconscious.

@graph.name: End of the round
@graph.description: A round ends when no one has AP left, nor action surge. When the round ends, all characters regain their AP. Any AP that was not spent in the previous round can be combined with that of the next round to rest, recovering STA.

@graph.name: Ending a turn
@graph.description: Once all desired actions have been performed or prepared, a character can end their turn. They can save as many AP as they want.

@graph.name: Enhance Spell
@graph.description: Increases the sorcery DC by 4 to improve spells in a special way described in the spell.

@graph.name: Environmental and ongoing effects
@graph.description: Any effect that occurs periodically per turn or is environmental has its effect applied at the beginning of the round.

@graph.name: Equipment Breakage
@graph.description: Objects are composed of two components: Resistance and Tenacity. They can take damage whenever they collide with something else, whether the collision is caused by themselves or the other object.

@graph.name: Escape
@graph.description: The objective is to evade pursuers or reach a safe place.

@graph.name: Escort/Kidnapping
@graph.description: The objective is to transport a character.

@graph.name: Evade
@graph.description: The defender spends 2AP to try to get out of the way of an attack. On a glancing blow, the attack has 50

@graph.name: Evasion
@graph.description: When the character is targeted by projectiles, they can spend 2 AP to react. This AP cost is used to move and does not need to be spent again, but any STA cost must be paid. Upon receiving a critical or hit, take the attack normally and then use up to 2 AP to move if not interrupted. On a graze, the character can jump to try to gain cover before being hit and only takes half damage if they fail. On a miss, the character does not take the attack and can spend their movement surge immediately to escape or do the same as in the graze.

@graph.name: Evasive Jump
@graph.description: is the most defensive option. It costs an extra 1 STA and allows the character to jump back and away from the attack while blocking or evading an attack. This movement cannot be followed and gives +AGI/3 on the skill test. This can only be used if there is space to jump away from the source of the attack.

@graph.name: Event DC
@graph.description: The DC of events varies between -5 and 15. The character can receive bonuses for traveling if they know the location they are heading to and for searching if they know where the item they are looking for is supposed to be.

@graph.name: Exploding die
@graph.description: In skill tests, if the result of the d10 is 10, roll 1d6 and add that to the score, continuing to add while the result is 6. If the result of the d10 is 1, do not add anything and then roll 1d6 and subtract the result instead of adding. Continue subtracting while rolling 6.

@graph.name: Exploration
@graph.description: It is used in survival situations to determine the ability to travel without getting lost and to find things in varied terrains. The exploration skill is based on the sum of detection proficiency and specific knowledge of the area.

@graph.name: Exploration Action
@graph.description: There are 4 exploration actions:

@graph.name: Exploration Turn (ET)
@graph.description: It is convenient to divide a day into blocks of 4 hours because it splits a day into 6 parts. The day has 24 hours: 8 hours of travel, 8 hours of sleep, 4 hours to set up camp and search for food, and 4 hours to fix anything that goes wrong or do something else. Each block of 4 hours is considered an exploration turn.

@graph.name: Explosion Block
@graph.description: Can only be done with a shield. Make an active reflex + shield deflection test against the DL of the explosion. If successful or critical, they have cover against the explosion and reduce its damage by RES, TGH, and INS from the shield.

@graph.name: Explosions
@graph.description: This type of attack results from something like a bomb, which radiates from a central point and loses strength with distance. Explosions are defended against with a reflex test. If the explosion comes from a projectile, the DL of the explosion is equal to the shooting skill. If the explosion occurs before being perceived, no test can be made. If the bomb is perceived, players receive a certain amount of AP to move away before it occurs.

@graph.name: Extend Charge Duration
@graph.description: Increases the sorcery DC by 2 to increase the charge duration of charged spells by +50

@graph.name: Extend Spell
@graph.description: Increases the sorcery DC by 2 to increase the range of a spell according to the MM.

@graph.name: Faction - name
@graph.description: Knowledge about the people of a faction, their history, politics, wealth, alliances, etiquette, etc.

@graph.name: Fear
@graph.description: Receives -1 Mental and cannot make a fight surge. The fear ends when the character succeeds on their Will check or becomes angry.

@graph.name: Flee
@graph.description: It is possible to activate the movement surge as a reaction for a character to prevent them from entering melee range or getting any closer. The action must be performed immediately before the opponent enters range. Only the AP gained from the movement surge can be used with this reaction.

@graph.name: Follow
@graph.description: A character can, as a reaction to any movement, follow another character who is within melee range. The action must be performed simultaneously with the triggering movement and cannot cost more AP than it.

@graph.name: Food
@graph.description: Provides a quantity of food or presents a test to obtain food.

@graph.name: Full Armor
@graph.description: is the traditional armor of the medieval knight. Those who wear such armor want to survive a rain of steel or expend all their energy in attacking while letting the armor defend them. It comes standard with gauntlets and a closed helmet, providing superior coverage and preventing almost any attack from hitting a vulnerable point. Its thick steel plates offer high resistance against all types of damage, and its rigidity is so high that it is common for more fragile weapons, like swords, to break upon impact. Adventuring in this armor is extremely tiring. There is an even more exaggerated version of this armor, which is the reinforced one.

@graph.name: Gaining Experience (XP)
@graph.description: Improving skills and proficiencies and learning abilities requires training during free time, which yields experience based on training time. A regular training session for skills and proficiencies takes 10 days for 1 XP and costs a certain amount of money based on the difficulty level of what one wants to learn.

@graph.name: Gauntlets
@graph.description: Gauntlets give -3 to prestidigitation, -3 to accuracy and climbing, but the armor protects the vulnerability of the hands. A pair of gauntlets costs 15 GP or 15

@graph.name: Gauntlets and closed helmet
@graph.description: It is possible to remove the gloves and closed helmets, but removing each of these eliminates their bonuses.

@graph.name: getting up
@graph.description: Removes the fallen condition.

@graph.name: Grapple
@graph.description: This attack is used for grappling actions.

@graph.name: Grapple Maneuvers
@graph.description: These are performed during a grapple by any of the participants in order to

@graph.name: Grappled
@graph.description: -3 Mobility. Movement requires pushing, and attacks can only be made with short-range or small weapons.

@graph.name: Grappling Hook and Rope
@graph.description: it is a weapon that, when it hits, allows you to pull a target. It is also a weapon that requires reload time, making multiple shots difficult. The grappling hook and rope can also be used as a climbing tool.

@graph.name: Greatcoat
@graph.description: is made from materials designed to protect the user in battle. It can be made of special leather or some durable plant fiber. Its great advantage is the mobility it provides, combined with reasonable protection against medium piercing weapons. If the user is hit directly by blades, the material will give way, but in the case of grazes, the damage should be completely mitigated. There may be variations of the armor with greater rigidity or less weight.

@graph.name: Greatsword
@graph.description: is a larger and more robust version of a longsword. Although the weapon is quite heavy, it is balanced so that its attack can still be delivered with agility. The blade is very durable, making the weapon ideal for destroying other weapons that attempt to block it. Its sweeping attack with enhanced damage and long reach makes it excellent for dealing with many opponents at once. This sword is too large to be used in grappling combat, but it is still capable of thrusting at vulnerable points.

@graph.name: Grenade
@graph.description: it is a throwable explosive. The grenade can be magically activated in different ways to produce various effects.

@graph.name: Guard
@graph.description: If using a shield, they can spend 2 AP to guard against ranged attacks coming from one direction as a reaction. All ranged attacks within a 180-degree semicircle in front of the character are made against the DL of reflexes + shield deflection without additional AP cost. The guard is canceled if the character performs any action other than careful movement.

@graph.name: Halberd
@graph.description: is a long-shafted weapon with a tip composed of an axe head, a spear point, and a hook. The axe head delivers devastating attacks against objects of low rigidity. The spear point allows the halberd to be used as a short spear with two hands. The hook is used to pull opponents, knocking them to the ground or disarming them.

@graph.name: Half Armor
@graph.description: is a lighter version of full armor. Several of the more restrictive pieces are removed so that the armor remains medium. As it retains the steel breastplate, it is very good against projectiles. Only those who find a gap in the armor will be able to injure the wearer. This type of armor is often chosen by archers in open field battles.

@graph.name: Hand
@graph.description: Has no armor unless it has gauntlets. A serious injury renders the hand useless. Deadly injuries or worse amputate the hand. Ranged attacks have -5 to hit.

@graph.name: Handle
@graph.description: This attack represents the handle of the weapon.

@graph.name: Hauberk
@graph.description: the first and lightest of the medium armors. It is made of thicker rings than the chain shirt and provides better coverage for the legs and neck. As it is still a fairly flexible armor, it allows heavy impacts to injure its user, but it also offers few penalties to mobility.

@graph.name: Head
@graph.description: receives -5 to hit, but injuries caused are increased by 1 degree of severity. Attacks that cause interruption and are serious or deadly leave the character unconscious.

@graph.name: Healing Injuries
@graph.description: Injuries have a certain amount of healing required to recover. Generally, light injuries require 2, serious injuries require 10, and deadly injuries require 20. Healing is obtained by resting well and using healing magic or potions. Some injuries are very debilitating. These require some type of advanced alternative method to fix, such as a prosthetic or a high-level spell capable of growing or reconnecting limbs.

@graph.name: Health
@graph.description: The character's ability to heal wounds and resist toxins. The use of health is described in the chapter on survival.

@graph.name: Heavy
@graph.description: Attacks with the "heavy" property have a heavy attack that costs +2AP+1STA.

@graph.name: Heavy Attack
@graph.description: It is possible to make a heavy attack with weapons that have the "heavy" property. Heavy I adds +0.5xSTR to the impact and increases the cost by +1AP+1STA. Heavy II adds +1xSTR to the impact, costs +2AP+1STA, and gives a -2 penalty to hit. Heavy III adds +1.5xSTR to the impact, costs +3AP+1STA, and gives a -3 penalty to hit.

@graph.name: Heavy Bow
@graph.description: this type of bow is so heavy that only the heaviest armors can stop its arrows. The strength required to draw such a bow is so great that very few humanoids are capable of using it. This weapon can use larger arrows, intended to take down large animals and heavily armored soldiers.

@graph.name: Heavy I/II/III
@graph.description: Allows for heavy attacks.

@graph.name: Hook
@graph.description: This attack can be used to knock down.

@graph.name: Horror
@graph.description: Stress mechanics. Characters lose control. Lighting. Time.

@graph.name: How to acquire
@graph.description: can be exchanged for 4 karma. It is possible to have a maximum of 4 vices. Overcoming vices costs 6 karma.

@graph.name: How to do it?
@graph.description: Social actions are performed through character interpretation. A character says or does something and declares the social action they are trying to perform. A charm or stress test is made against a DC that varies from case to case, and the effects of the action are resolved. If the social action is performed within a combat context, the Master may decide to require a certain amount of Action Points (AP) to perform it.

@graph.name: Immobile
@graph.description: Cannot move and cannot use any combat skill other than escape the grapple. The SD is reduced to -5 + SMx1. Armor coverage is reduced by an extra -3.

@graph.name: Immobile Targets and Shooting Errors
@graph.description: The DL to hit an immobile target occupying a space of 1m is equal to -5-2*SM. If a projectile misses the test, it hits some adjacent space or a distance even greater for every 3 points the test is below the DL.

@graph.name: Immobilize
@graph.description: The opponent becomes immobilized on a critical. It is possible to stay immobilized yourself to achieve immobilization on a hit.

@graph.name: Impact
@graph.description: is the component that represents the total force applied with the blow. If the impact is greater than or equal to natural RES + armor protection, the injury is light. If it is greater than or equal to 2x RES + armor protection, it is serious. If it is greater than or equal to 3x RES + armor protection, it is deadly. If the total impact is greater than 6xRES + armor protection, the target receives three deadly injuries.

@graph.name: Impact/PEN
@graph.description: indicates the impact and its penetration. PEN is an estimate of penetration capability based on the speed of the attack, contact area, and hardness of the attacking material.

@graph.name: Impress
@graph.description: The goal of impressing is to make a character consider you a contact temporarily. This test is the same as the persuasion test or an acting test. On successes or criticals, the target considers you a contact until the end of the interaction or until trust is betrayed.

@graph.name: Improving attributes
@graph.description: The XP cost to improve attributes is equal to the target attribute value divided by 2. However, if the sum of the 3 attributes plus the target value exceeds $40+4*CON-4*SM$, the cost is doubled. For every 3 points higher, it triples, and so on for every 3 points.

@graph.name: Improving Talents
@graph.description: During character creation, the player must choose the character's talents in order of priority. After that, talents can only be increased by spending karma. The karma cost to increase a talent is equal to $4+4*n$, where n is the talent level one wishes to acquire. The maximum talent value is 5.

@graph.name: Increase in severity
@graph.description: If the character has already reached their limit of light injuries, each additional light injury becomes serious, and so on. The amount of healing required to recover from these injuries is that of the original damage, before the increase.

@graph.name: Increase Spell
@graph.description: Increases the sorcery DC by 4 to amplify spells. It can be used when the spell has its effects multiplied by DM, SM, MM, and VM. The number of times it can be increased depends on environmental conditions and the material used. The amount of material or charges consumed is multiplied by the VM. Increase Spell allows it to apply to larger versions of the items.

@graph.name: Increasing a creature
@graph.description: The strength of a creature increases with the cross-sectional area of a muscle, while weight increases with volume. Therefore, when increasing the size of a creature without changing its shape, it receives a penalty of -1 STR and -1 natural AGI.

@graph.name: Initiate the Grab
@graph.description: attackers must make a strike test with a weapon that haS the grapple property against the opponent's defense or SD. On a hit or critical, the opponent is grappled, and the evasive jump movement is canceled. If the opponent does not attempt to defend the attack, grapple succeeds on a graze. Creatures 2 sizes larger do not suffer the effects of being grabbed by smaller ones.

@graph.name: Injuries
@graph.description: They are categorized as light, serious, and deadly. A character can acquire injuries by taking damage in any form. The amount of damage will determine the severity of the injury. The number of injuries a character can sustain before succumbing depends on their constitution and abilities.

@graph.name: Injury
@graph.description: Strike, Accuracy, Defend, Reflex, Climb, Balance, Stealth, Swim, Prestidigitation, Strength, and Grapple.

@graph.name: Interpretation Bonus (IB)
@graph.description: Interpretation is a very important factor in determining the effectiveness of social actions. If the player's interpretation in the scene is not suitable for the social action they are trying to perform, a negative IB should be applied. The action may even be denied by the Master. In cases where the probability of the social action succeeding is very high and the interpretation has been very good, a high positive IB may be granted. The bonuses and penalties should range between +10 and -10.

@graph.name: Interruption
@graph.description: is an effect that causes the victim to lose their action and associated costs when it occurs during an action or causes a minimum loss of 2 AP. Interruption occurs whenever a character receives an injury from impact or electric damage. Multiple simultaneous interruptions cause the greater of the loss of AP equal to 2x the number of interruptions or equal to the AP loss of the interrupted action.

@graph.name: Intimidate
@graph.description: is an attempt to instill fear in someone or to persuade through threat. For the intimidation IB, one must analyze the likelihood of the threat being carried out and the cost of accepting the threat. It is done with a stress test against Will.

@graph.name: Intrigue
@graph.description: Social. Progress in relationships with NPCs. Social skills. Reputation.

@graph.name: jumping
@graph.description: A jump has a vertical distance equal to half the horizontal distance. If performed during a run, increase the horizontal distance of a long jump to AGI/3. Movement cannot be voluntarily interrupted in the middle of a jump. If performed backward, the horizontal distance is halved.

@graph.name: Karma
@graph.description: is used to increase talents. It is received upon completing missions and their secondary objectives, as well as being rewarded for good gameplay.

@graph.name: Knockdown
@graph.description: A melee attack with a hook weapon that attempts to knock down the opponent. The attack costs an additional +1STA. If it is a critical, it knocks down the opponent with impact > natural RES. If it is a hit, it knocks down with impact > 2x natural RES. Gains +0.5xSTR if the opponent attempts to perform an evasive jump or is running. This can be used as a reaction against mounted targets that move away from the weapon within its melee range.

@graph.name: Knowledge as a skill
@graph.description: The purest way to use knowledge is as a skill:

@graph.name: Knowledge as a talent
@graph.description: Knowledge can be used as a talent to learn spells. Spells have a knowledge requirement indicating the difficulty.

@graph.name: Lame
@graph.description: Cannot run, jump, or perform basic movement.

@graph.name: Language
@graph.description: Knowledge about a specific language. Having level 4 in a language is necessary for fluent speech.

@graph.name: Leg
@graph.description: Cannot cause sudden death, but serious injuries leave the character lame. Deadly injuries or worse amputate the leg.

@graph.name: Level 0, Novice
@graph.description: Knows only what is common sense

@graph.name: Level 1, Apprentice
@graph.description: Can do the basics

@graph.name: Level 2, Amateur
@graph.description: Masters the basics and has some advanced knowledge

@graph.name: Level 3, Professional
@graph.description: Works at a professional level

@graph.name: Level 4, Expert
@graph.description: Capable of reproducing almost anything in the field

@graph.name: Level 5, Master
@graph.description: Capable of producing results of the highest level.

@graph.name: Level 6, Grandmaster
@graph.description: Is pushing the boundaries of knowledge in their era.

@graph.name: Level Limits
@graph.description: The values of talent and proficiency range from 0 to 5, and cannot be increased beyond that. Skills can be increased indefinitely, but they become exponentially more expensive since the maximum talent is 5.

@graph.name: Light
@graph.description: Every 2 light injuries inflict a -1 injury affliction. A light injury takes 2 healing to be cured by default.

@graph.name: Load penalties
@graph.description: The penalties shown in the armor and shield tables derive from the additional weight of the armor and are reflected in the AGI attribute values and as an increase in the action surge cost by penalty/3. During travel, it also affects the STA value used to determine wear. The penalties stack.

@graph.name: Localized damage and vulnerability
@graph.description: Each type of creature may have points that must be specifically aimed at when using the attack, called vulnerabilities. When someone declares that they are aiming at that specific point, the attack is modified according to the description of the vulnerability.

@graph.name: Location - place
@graph.description: Knowledge about the people in the town and their local customs.

@graph.name: Long Bow
@graph.description: it is the most common bow on the battlefield. It has enough power to penetrate medium armor when it hits directly. Drawing a bow like this requires above-average muscle strength.

@graph.name: Longsword
@graph.description: is the most iconic weapon of knights, marking its users as people of status. Its cuts with the blade are very quick and effective against lightly armored opponents, in addition to having good reach and being usable against several opponents at once. The blade can also be used defensively to block. The longsword also has a sharp tip, which provides an attack with more penetration than the blade's cut. Another option is to thrust while holding the blade, reducing the reach but increasing penetration and allowing for attacks during grappling. Its tip is a precise attack, making it good for hitting vulnerable points. Furthermore, the sword also has a pommel, which can be used as an alternative for blunt damage. Longswords truly shine in the hands of more skilled characters.

@graph.name: Loyalty to the character
@graph.description: This means the player acts in ways that the character would, rather than what the player thinks is best.

@graph.name: Mace
@graph.description: It is a weapon focused on taking down armored opponents. Its best feature is its heavy strike, which is relatively quick compared to the heavy strikes of other weapons. The durability of the mace is very high when used offensively, but its shaft makes it fragile defensively. Some maces can be made entirely of metal.

@graph.name: Materials and Hardness
@graph.description: There are 4 levels of material hardness. The first is for liquids. The second is for fabrics, flesh, flexible armors, and similar materials. The third is for wood and horns. The fourth is for metals and rocks. Collisions involving materials of hardness 1 and 2 do not pose a risk of breakage from impact to any of the materials.

@graph.name: Mental
@graph.description: Strike, Accuracy, Reflex, Climb, Balance, Stealth, Prestidigitation, Exploration, Cunning, Spells, Will, Knowledge.

@graph.name: Mobility
@graph.description: Strike, Accuracy, Defend, Reflex, Climb, Balance, Stealth, and Swim.

@graph.name: Moral test
@graph.description: At the beginning of each round, all characters make a will test against the terror of the moment. A graze leaves the character frightened, and a failure activates the character's limit stress action.

@graph.name: Mounted Combat
@graph.description: Attacking in melee receives a mount-dependent penalty while mounted, usually around -2. Accuracy receives the penalty while the mount is moving, not when standing still. Moving while mounted is considered running to trigger reactions, unless stated otherwise. If the character is forcibly displaced while mounted, they will be dismounted.

@graph.name: mounted movement
@graph.description: A character needs minimum training to be able to use a mount. During mounted combat, the character's movement speed matches that of the mount, but they must spend an extra 1 AP to give a movement command, such as run and stop (not changing direction if the change is less than or equal to 60 degrees). Poorly trained mounts respond more slowly. Mounting and dismounting costs AP equal to standing up.

@graph.name: Movement Multiplier (MM)
@graph.description: multiplies all movement speeds and the range of all weapons.

@graph.name: Moving Targets
@graph.description: It is possible to shoot at moving targets as a reaction. The total amount of AP spent to shoot cannot exceed the amount of AP spent on movement. The AP count starts when the target becomes visible. The target's position at the moment of the shot is where it is at the end of the movement.

@graph.name: Mutation Level
@graph.description: Skills that have Mutation +x in their cost increase the character's Mutation level.

@graph.name: Negative AP
@graph.description: AP can become a negative number, but never as a result of performing an action or reaction. When the character recovers their AP, they must deduct the negative value from their maximum.

@graph.name: Net
@graph.description: it is a good weapon for ambushes or hunts. When thrown against groups of opponents, it can provide a decisive advantage by entangling several of them. Its preparation time is very long, making it impractical to throw multiple times in the same combat.

@graph.name: Note on difficulties
@graph.description: When designing DLs, to put things in perspective, consider that a DL of -5 is trivial, 0 is average, 5 is difficult, and 10 is very difficult.

@graph.name: Notoriety
@graph.description: +3 Stress. ranges from 1-10

@graph.name: NPC Encounters
@graph.description: The player characters are not the only ones in the wild. Here are some ideas of who they might encounter: A child is found alone in the forest. A cabin is found in the middle of the path during a snowstorm, but the owner does not want to let anyone in. A merchant is stuck on the road with a broken cart wheel. A werewolf is found camping in the forest and offers shelter in their camp.

@graph.name: Obstacle
@graph.description: It can be a puzzle, a door, a physical challenge, a natural disaster, etc.

@graph.name: Opportunity Attack
@graph.description: A melee weapon attack that can be used as a reaction when an opponent attempts to perform a triggering action. It is possible to cancel the triggering action and reuse the AP spent to defend against an opportunity attack, but not with evasive jump. The attack requires the normal AP cost and has a +2 bonus to hit. Triggering actions include casting spells that cost 3 AP or more, using ranged weapons, using a standard action, standing up, and moving towards a melee weapon while within its attack range. The attack occurs before the effect of the triggering action, unless stated otherwise.

@graph.name: Padded Armor
@graph.description: is a garment with many layers made of cotton or linen, accompanied by boots and a metal helmet. It is very thick, which makes it heavy and reduces the user's mobility. This armor surprisingly offers good protection, but it is not made of a material designed to withstand many cuts. This is the type of armor a peasant would wear if called to fight and had to find something at the last minute. It is a very cheap item relative to the value of other armors.

@graph.name: Participation in dramatic events
@graph.description: Speeches, discussions between characters, exploration, and conversations that show curiosity about the world, demonstration of the character's ethical and moral flaws, and comedic moments.

@graph.name: Passive encounter
@graph.description: The characters must find this. It can be anything that generates social interaction or combat.

@graph.name: Penetration
@graph.description: is the component that represents the ability to cut the target. Sharper and harder weapons have greater penetration. If the PEN is greater than or equal to the armor's toughness (TGH), the injury is light. If it is greater than or equal to 2x TGH + TGH of the armor, it is serious. If it is greater than or equal to 3x TGH + TGH of the armor, it is deadly. If the total damage is greater than 6xTGH + TGH of the armor, the target dies instantly. If the attack causes an injury from penetration, it ignores the armor's insulation.

@graph.name: Persuade
@graph.description: is an attempt to influence a character to do what one wants or to believe what is being said. Persuasion is a charm test against stress. The better the test result, the more the target does what the other wants and believes what has been said. The worse the result, the more they do what benefits themselves or detect that they are being deceived. To determine the IB of a persuasion test, the NPC's disposition, the risk, the cost, and the return of the proposal should be analyzed.

@graph.name: Physical damage
@graph.description: There are two components to consider when receiving injuries from physical attacks: Impact (IMP) and penetration(PEN). Attacks and effects that cause injuries will have some amount of each of these components.

@graph.name: Pick Lock
@graph.description: These tests require knowledge of mechanics and receive -5 for each level below the requirement. On criticals, it takes 5 AP. On successes, between 10 seconds and 1 minute. On a graze, it takes between 10 minutes and 1 hour, and on a failure, it is impossible to open.

@graph.name: Polearm
@graph.description: is the melee weapon with the greatest reach. Being a weapon capable of delivering braced attacks, it is excellent for keeping opponents at bay and discouraging charges. They have a shaft of approximately 3m in length, making them very inconvenient in enclosed spaces.

@graph.name: Popularity
@graph.description: Ranges from 1-10

@graph.name: Precise
@graph.description: Increases the chance of overcoming armor coverage by +3 or by +5 in case of small weapons. There is a +100

@graph.name: Preparation
@graph.description: At the start of combat, the miniatures are positioned in their locations, and each character starts with 6 AP by default. They also receive a turn token, which they can spend to take their turn.

@graph.name: Prepared Shots
@graph.description: If a character prepares a ranged attack, the shot occurs when the target becomes visible.

@graph.name: Preparing a reaction
@graph.description: Any action can be prepared on a player's turn, but doing so costs 1 AP. This allows the player to create any trigger they can imagine for a reaction. They must have enough AP to perform the reaction when the trigger occurs. A prepared action can consist of a movement and a use of skill and can be repeated multiple times as long as the trigger happens again.

@graph.name: Prohibited Attitudes
@graph.description: Loses 1 XP each time they fail or graze by on a test that is not risky.

@graph.name: Promoted Attitudes
@graph.description: Learns to take any test in a risky manner. Gains 1XP each time they roll a 9 or 10 on a risky test.

@graph.name: Prone
@graph.description: -3 Mobility. Can only crawl and stand up.

@graph.name: Protect
@graph.description: It is possible to defend an ally by staying within their melee range and the attack at the same time. The defender can redirect or block an attack directed at an ally.}

@graph.name: Provoke
@graph.description: is an attempt to instill anger in someone. When a character tries to infuriate another by appealing to their vanity, pride, or frustration. It is a stress test resisted by Will.

@graph.name: Push
@graph.description: Can be used during a grapple. Make a strength check opposed by the opponent's strength or balance. The defender must also spend 2 AP + 1 STA to resist; otherwise, they receive -5 on the check. A success pushes the enemy 1 space, while a critical knocks them down. Gains +2 when performed during a run.

@graph.name: Quick Shot
@graph.description: Modifies the shot to cost 1 AP less to shoot, but incurs a -3 penalty in accuracy and -3 in distance instead of -2.

@graph.name: Rank and reputation
@graph.description: Rank and reputation play important roles in military hierarchy and command structure.

@graph.name: Rapier
@graph.description: It is the fastest one-handed long weapon available. They are excellent for duels against lightly armored opponents, as their flurries of strikes are very difficult to defend against, and their range provides a significant advantage over shorter weapons. Rapiers are commonly seen in urban settings and are easily carried in enclosed spaces. They are often used in conjunction with shields or daggers, as these enhance their defensive potential and open opponents up to counterattacks.

@graph.name: Reactions
@graph.description: These are actions that can be performed on another character's turn but must be triggered by something. An example is trying to evade an attack, which is triggered when being attacked. A reaction takes effect before the action that caused it.

@graph.name: Receiving XP
@graph.description: Downtime activities generate experience in knowledge. The character receives XP in knowledge simply by having access to related information. The amount generated will depend on the character's dedication and ability to learn. For example, if the character is in a town but spends all their time learning sorcery in a tower, they do not gain local knowledge. If they stay in the tavern meeting new people and celebrating, but do not know the language, they gain a lot of knowledge about the language, but less about the local area.

@graph.name: Redirect
@graph.description: makes a defensive attack against a weapon by spending 3 AP. On a glancing blow, the attack impact is reduced by STR for one-handed weapons and by 2xSTR for two-handed weapons or shields. On a miss, the impact is further reduced by +1xSTR. The resulting impact hits the defender and is used to calculate the PEN. Redirect has a +3 bonus against long weapons if the characters are at close range.

@graph.name: Religion - name
@graph.description: Knowledge about the gods of a religion and their domains.

@graph.name: Reload
@graph.description: The weapon requires reloading to attack again.

@graph.name: Resistance
@graph.description: Is the ability to absorb impact. If impact > RES, the object breaks.

@graph.name: Resistance/stiffness
@graph.description: indicates the Resistance of the attack.

@graph.name: Respect
@graph.description: +3 Charm. ranges from 1-10

@graph.name: Reward for specific feats
@graph.description: XP can also be generated by specific events. For example, experiencing multiple exploration events in a certain region can generate survival XP in that region.

@graph.name: Rigid armors
@graph.description: have a hardness of 3 or 4, which means they receive and deal damage from weapons that hit them, thus having a RES value. Their protection against impact is greater, as the armor absorbs a larger portion.

@graph.name: Rondel
@graph.description: is a dagger focused on destroying armored opponents. Its penetration is quite high, making opponents wearing a chain shirt or chainmail extremely vulnerable. Being a small weapon with short range, the rondel is ideal for grappling combat. Even when its penetration is insufficient against armor, the rondel, being a precise weapon, can devastate the opponent if it lands a vulnerable attack.

@graph.name: running
@graph.description: Can only be initiated during a movement surge, but can continue running after accelerating as long as no turns of 90 degrees or more are made per running block. The character can run a partial amount smaller than its running speed, but AP cost is the same.

@graph.name: Safe and risky tests
@graph.description: It is possible to perform some tests safely or riskily. In the safe form, roll 2 d10 and take the result closest to 5. Similarly, it is possible to perform tests in a risky manner. In this case, roll 2 d10 and take the result farthest from 5. This mechanic can only be used when indicated in the skill or ability or when the Master allows it.

@graph.name: Scandals, heroic deeds, completed missions
@graph.description: Reputation is part of the reward for playing the game. The higher the reputation, the harder it is to increase.

@graph.name: Seduce
@graph.description: is an attempt to instill the affliction of being seduced in a character. To seduce, the character must demonstrate the intention to romanticize the other. It is a charm test against stress to show good intentions and make the other feel at ease. The target becomes Charmed on successes and criticals.

@graph.name: Seduced
@graph.description: Receives -3 Mental against their charmer.

@graph.name: Sense Motivation
@graph.description: Cunning can also be used as a defense against social actions. This is equivalent to perceiving if someone is lying, has ulterior motives, or is hiding or pretending something.

@graph.name: Serious
@graph.description: Each serious injury inflicts a -1 injury affliction. A serious injury takes 10 healing to be cured by default.

@graph.name: Severe compulsions
@graph.description: Whenever a compulsion forces a character to perform an act that they perceive will cause physical harm to themselves or someone they care about, the compulsion is severe. In this case, the character has +5 to resist the compulsion.

@graph.name: Sharpening
@graph.description: Is an action that takes one exploration turn and increases the weapon's PEN by 25

@graph.name: Shelter
@graph.description: Setting up camp can be time-consuming without proper equipment. Characters can bring their own tent and sleeping bag. These tools can largely serve as protection against the elements without taking much time. If these items are not available, an exploration action to build a natural shelter must be performed. The effectiveness of the shelter is described in the shelter event, if it has been activated, or in the natural event of the node.

@graph.name: Shoot
@graph.description: Basic ranged attack with a shooting weapon. It cannot be blocked without a large or tower shield.

@graph.name: Short Bow
@graph.description: it is the lightest bow. The strength required to draw it is low, allowing for faster shooting techniques. Short bows have a shorter range and deal less damage than other bows, making them poor choices against resilient opponents. Short bows can use broadhead arrows for more damage or bodkin arrows for better penetration.

@graph.name: Short, Long I/II
@graph.description: Short-range attacks can be used in grappling combat but have a range of 1m x MM. Long-range attacks have an extended range of 1m x MM per level and cannot be used in grappling combat.

@graph.name: Short Rest
@graph.description: The character has the option to spend an exploration turn doing nothing, which recovers RV exhaustion.

@graph.name: Short Spear
@graph.description: The most common weapon on the battlefield. They can be used one-handed alongside shields or two-handed to increase strike speed. They can also be thrown, making them a very versatile weapon. Short spears are very cheap and common, but they are unusual in an urban environment and should be carried in one hand or strapped to the back. Due to being a wooden shaft weapon, the durability of spears can become an issue when used against highly rigid objects or when used to block cutting weapons.

@graph.name: Short Sword
@graph.description: It is a larger version of a dagger, suitable for public use without drawing attention and easy to draw. Although it is too large to be ideal for grappling combat, it has stronger attacks and offers better defensive potential. It is a good secondary weapon or for urban and enclosed environments.

@graph.name: Shot
@graph.description: indicates that the ranged attack can be used, as well as the precise shot and quick shot. It cannot be redirected, only absorbed.

@graph.name: Size x
@graph.description: Defines which size of creature can wield the weapon. Wielding a weapon that is larger than appropriate gives a -3 penalty to hit the attack, increases the cost of AP and STA for all attacks by +1, and uses STR-5 in the contribution of STR to damage. This penalty applies to any contribution of STR for any attack, including braced, hooked, and heavy. Wielding a weapon 2 size categories larger is impossible.

@graph.name: Skill Modifier (SM)
@graph.description: is a modifier added to or subtracted from the character's values, in the proportions shown in the table.

@graph.name: Skill test
@graph.description: A skill test consists of a dice roll to determine the degree of success in performing an action. Tests are made by rolling a 10-sided die and adding the result to the skill value. This sum is compared to a difficulty level to determine the degree of success of the action.

@graph.name: Small/One/Two hands
@graph.description: Small weapons can be easily concealed and slipped into small cracks. One-handed weapons require only one hand to attack and defend. Two-handed weapons require both hands to attack and block.

@graph.name: Snipe
@graph.description: Modifies the shot to cost an additional 2 AP to gain +2 in accuracy and shoot with a -1 distance penalty instead of -2 for the first 50m.

@graph.name: Sorcery
@graph.description: Uses sorcery proficiency added to a related knowledge to cast spells. More details are in the combat section.

@graph.name: Special Failure
@graph.description: If the total skill value is less than 5 due to a natural 1, something especially bad may happen, such as breaking a weapon, dropping all arrows from the quiver, or falling. This is an optional rule, and its application is entirely at the Master's discretion.

@graph.name: Sprays
@graph.description: They are a type of explosion, with the same damage progression based on distance from the origin and the same DL definition mechanic. Sprays target all characters in a way that no two targets are more than 180 degrees apart in a circle centered at the origin of the spray. All targets make their reflex saves to escape, just like in explosions and move their characters according to their result. After the movement, the spray damages only one of the targets, at the attacker's choice.

@graph.name: Standard Action
@graph.description: Consider that 1 AP is equal to half a second and estimate how long an action should take. In general, taking an item from a belt or strap around the armor should take about 3 AP, while opening a backpack and taking something costs about 5 seconds. The AP cost of a standard action is 3 AP.

@graph.name: Standard Deflection (SD)
@graph.description: is the standard difficulty to hit a target, which is based solely on its size and movement. The larger the target, the easier it is to hit. The standard deflection is equal to -5-1xSM for stationary targets and -2-1xSM for moving targets. It is impossible for any type of penalty to reduce a character's deflection to a value lower than the SD.

@graph.name: Start
@graph.description: Combat occurs when a group decides to fight against another. A combat is played in rounds, which represent 3 seconds of game time each.

@graph.name: Stealth
@graph.description: The objective is to go unnoticed.

@graph.name: Stealth and Sorcery
@graph.description: Spells are imperceptible before they have their effect, unless a skill is used to reveal them. Once their effect occurs, they can be identified with a test of the skill used to cast the spell.

@graph.name: Step 1
@graph.description: Choose the character focus. Wealth, DEX, CON, INT, or SPI. Assign each focus a priority level, from A to E.

@graph.name: STR x
@graph.description: Strength requirement.

@graph.name: Suffocation
@graph.description: If the character cannot breathe during the turn of a round, they lose 1 STA and cannot rest.

@graph.name: Supplies
@graph.description: Supply management includes:

@graph.name: Surprise
@graph.description: A combat can start with characters being surprised. In this case, all characters who are surprised begin the first round with 0 AP.

@graph.name: Survival and adventure
@graph.description: Exploration mechanics. Management of inventory, sleep, thirst, and hunger.

@graph.name: Survival - region
@graph.description: Knowledge about a specific region, its roads and paths, food sources, water sources, natural disasters, economic resources, geographical landmarks, etc. This type of knowledge is often used alongside survival actions like traveling and searching.

@graph.name: Sustained Spells
@graph.description: are actions that can be performed continuously while concentration is maintained. Their effect ends when the caster stops concentrating on it. For these spells, the sorcery skill test needs to be redone periodically, as indicated in the spell. A failure in the sorcery test interrupts the sustained magic.

@graph.name: Sweeping
@graph.description: Allows for Sweeping attacks.

@graph.name: Sweeping Attack
@graph.description: spends 1 additional AP on the attack and hits everything in a semicircle. Decide whether to attack from right to left or vice versa and attack the enemies in that order in a 180-degree arc. If the attack is blocked or redirected, the impact is reduced for all. If one character is behind another, only the closest is hit. Sweeping attacks do not hit fallen enemies. There is no size bonus or penalty to strike in sweeping attacks.

@graph.name: swimming
@graph.description: is the only usable movement speed while swimming. It also applies the

@graph.name: Tanatosis
@graph.description: Falls to the ground paralyzed for 1 turn and rests 2 times.

@graph.name: Target number (TN)
@graph.description: Works like the DL, but the action has a hit or miss. In this case, if the test value is greater than or equal to the TN, the action is a success; otherwise, it is a failure.

@graph.name: Tenacity
@graph.description: is the ability to resist cuts, that is, PEN. If PEN > TGH, the equipment breaks.

@graph.name: Terrain Wear
@graph.description: Each terrain has a value that represents how pleasant it is to spend time there. This value is used to determine the RV for resting. Generally, the value ranges from 0 to 5 but can even be negative.

@graph.name: Tests and the role of dice
@graph.description: Skills are the mechanism used to perform tests. All tests use one of the 20 skills.

@graph.name: Theft
@graph.description: The objective is to acquire an object.

@graph.name: Throw
@graph.description: Basic ranged attack with a throwable weapon. Throwable weapons gain range based on STR.

@graph.name: Traitor
@graph.description: is compelled to use their utility surge to negotiate with the opponent. If the target is unable to communicate, they run for 1 turn.

@graph.name: trample
@graph.description: The character attempts to pass through an occupied space. If the opponent does not move out of the way, they must perform a push action to stop the movement.

@graph.name: Treasure
@graph.description: It can be anything of monetary or experience value.

@graph.name: Troops
@graph.description: Troops are divided into squads. Types of troops have different characteristics: power, consumption, load, and loyalty.

@graph.name: Turn order
@graph.description: It is defined by a "first to ask, first to play" rule. If several players want to play at the same time, all interested make a cunning test, and the one who rolls the highest goes first.

@graph.name: Types of damage
@graph.description: are: physical, burn, electric, radiant, and corrosive. Objects and creatures may have resistance or vulnerability to each of these types of damage.

@graph.name: Types of Ranged Attacks
@graph.description: Other types of ranged attacks will be available depending on the type of weapon used. The type of attack must be declared when used, and only one can be used at a time unless stated otherwise.

@graph.name: Unarmed
@graph.description: Corresponds to the hands of a humanoid character. It has punch and grapple as attacks. The punch deals damage based on the character's strength. A punch is unlikely to damage another character wearing armor, but since it is a small weapon with short range, it can land vulnerable hits with some ease. A heavy attack that overcomes armor coverage may be enough to knock someone out. The grapple does not deal damage, but serves both to hold the opponent and perform grappling maneuvers as well as to block some damage.

@graph.name: Unconscious
@graph.description: The character cannot do anything other than Will and Health checks. They can also make detection and sensing checks, but receive -10 on these checks. These checks can be made to wake up. The DL and the allowed check depend on the situation.

@graph.name: Varying XP cost
@graph.description: The amount of XP required to level up can also be arbitrary, depending on the difficulty of learning the knowledge. For example, knowing all the relevant people in a town of 400 inhabitants is much easier than learning a new language. INT is used as a talent for skills normally.

@graph.name: Victory Condition
@graph.description: A battle ends when:

@graph.name: Violent
@graph.description: is compelled to use their fight or utility surge to inflict damage on someone.

@graph.name: Visibility
@graph.description: The levels of visibility are visible, obscured, and invisible. If something is invisible, it is impossible to react to anything it does unless it is detected in some other way. It is still possible to perform a targeted action in the place where they are if the character knows where it is. Even so, the action will have the effect of blindness applied to it. If the target is obscured, any attacks against them or reactions to their actions receive the obscured effect.

@graph.name: Vision
@graph.description: Strike, Accuracy, Defend, Reflex, Climb, Balance, Stealth, Prestidigitation, Grapple, Exploration, Cunning.

@graph.name: War
@graph.description: Tactical movement of troops. Technological race. Supply and logistics management. Disposable characters. Helpers.

@graph.name: Warhammer
@graph.description: is the most reliable melee solution against heavily armored opponents. It is like a halberd, but the axe head is replaced with a heavy hammer. Attacking with the hammer consumes a lot of energy and time, but if it hits, a heavy blow will knock down most opponents. This weapon is best used in the hands of a strong character.

@graph.name: Water
@graph.description: Provides a quantity of water or presents a test to obtain water.

@graph.name: Weapon Breakage
@graph.description: A broken weapon can no longer be used and costs 50

@graph.name: Wear
@graph.description: Performing any exploration action that is not resting causes wear. The standard wear is 1 exhaustion, 1 hunger, and 1 thirst, and it is applied at the end of the exploration action. It is possible for the exploration action to have increased wear depending on the terrain. For example, performing any exploration action in the desert causes +1 thirst.

@graph.name: Whip
@graph.description: is the only light weapon with long range. Its damage and penetration are insufficient to injure any armored opponent, but its great advantage lies in the grapple attack. Keeping a target under control at a distance combined with the ability to drag it towards you can be a great strategic move against agile opponents, leaving them open to braced and opportunity attacks, as well as reducing their ability to defend. There are modified versions of whips, such as the electric whip, which allows electrical abilities to hit grappled opponents.

@graph.name: Accelerate Blooming
@graph.description: The plant will go through its seasonal stages very quickly, draining nutrients and water from the soil and bearing fruit if possible.

@graph.name: Accelerate Fermentation
@graph.description: Greatly accelerates the fermentation process of sugary substances, creating 500ml of alcohol.

@graph.name: Action Surge
@graph.formula: cost = 3 + floor(gear_penalty / 3); effect: STA -= cost; AP += 6

@graph.name: Adrenaline
@graph.description: The character can spend 1 extra STA to move the equivalent of one more AP of movement after the explosion or projectile.

@graph.name: Advanced Possession
@graph.description: Makes possession a favorite spell. During a possession, can regenerate 1 STA per hour.

@graph.name: Agile Build
@graph.description: Running speed increases by 1m per AP and gains +1m in height and long jump distance. All bonuses are revoked when armor penalty is higher than 1.

@graph.name: Alcoholic
@graph.description: Penalty of -3 for moral tests if not intoxicated, bonus of +1 if intoxicated. Gains 1/2/3 Hedonism XP for entering combat with alcoholism I/II or III, respectively.

@graph.name: Alter Memories
@graph.description: Touches the mind of a person and sees the memories of the things the person is talking about. Anything said by the caster to the person will be remembered as truth. The person can accept the ritual or resist it with will. In this case, a success or critical modifies the memory successfully. If the person accepts the ritual, a cleric of Rivka automatically succeeds in the ritual.

@graph.name: Ambusher
@graph.description: When making stealthy melee attacks with a small weapon, if the first attack is a critical hit, you can attack again before the opponent makes their detection check or has any reaction.

@graph.name: Amplified Pheromones
@graph.description: The character gains awareness and control over their pheromones, increasing the difficulty of any will or social cunning test by +2 for anyone within 6m.

@graph.name: Anchor Soul
@graph.description: Anchors a creature's soul to a soul stone, preventing it from disappearing. This can be done with the souls of creatures that have been dead for up to 10 minutes. If the soul is still present, resurrection is possible, but the soul will extinguish in 3 days without a body.

@graph.name: Animal Grafts
@graph.description: Allows performing grafts on plants and animals, enabling the learning of chimera mutation skills with sorcery.

@graph.name: Animate Dead
@graph.description: Animates a corpse with a fragment of its soul. It can only move and attack or grapple enemies. The caster can direct it to attack something, but selecting a new target costs 1 AP. If the target dies, the corpse will automatically seek another. Multiple animated corpses can be commanded at the same time. The corpse retains its strength, size, and resilience, but the rest of the attributes become 6. If out of combat, it is possible to attempt to speak with the undead. If the brain and vocal cords are intact, it can answer some questions.

@graph.name: Antidote
@graph.description: Attempts to manipulate the body of a living being to metabolize poison. Allows a redo of a health test to resist poison using the target's health +4, or an additional +2 for each enhancement.

@graph.name: Archer
@graph.description: Learns to shoot with bows, removing the penalty, and allows for quick and precise shots.

@graph.name: Archer's Muscles I/II
@graph.description: Provides a strength bonus of +1/2 to meet the strength requirement of bows.

@graph.name: Archer's Reflexes
@graph.description: Allows for a quick shot at any visible target in reaction to any action of the target that triggers an opportunity attack and the shooter has perceived.

@graph.name: Armorer
@graph.description: I. Allows the character to make simple repairs and maintain weapons and armor.

@graph.name: Assassination
@graph.description: Increases the bonus to hit vulnerable attacks against immobile opponents or from stealth by +2.

@graph.name: Aurora
@graph.description: Draws or writes a simple and blurred message in the sky that can be seen at night within the spell's range.

@graph.name: Avatar
@graph.description: Allows a spirit to possess the character's body. Can utilize all skill and proficiency bonuses of the spirit. Every time the spirit and the player disagree on an action or the player wants to expel the spirit from the body, a will test must be made. Whoever succeeds or crits will do things their way.

@graph.name: Bat Ears
@graph.description: Modifies the ears to pick up a wide range of frequencies and become more sensitive. Allows the character to see with their ears. Vision counts as dazzled, but it is omnidirectional and can be used to target foes.

@graph.name: Battle Coordination
@graph.description: When there are two allies within melee range of the same enemy, the enemy's attacks against one ally trigger opportunity attacks from the other, provided they have this ability. The opportunity attack occurs after what triggered it. Wide attacks do not trigger this, since it is made in an area.

@graph.name: Battle Mage I/II/III
@graph.description: I. Allows the wizard to move while concentrating, repurposing the same action points used for the spell. II. When interrupted, instead of losing the spell, redo the spellcasting test with a penalty of -3 and choose the worst result between the original and this one. III. Allows the use of active defense while concentrating.

@graph.name: Bear Nose
@graph.description: Modifies the nose to become very sensitive and can transform it into a snout. Allows for cunning tests using smell. You can detect someone passively and actively without penalty even if they hide and stay silent or hide.

@graph.name: Beautiful
@graph.description: Gains +1 on charm against any humanoid. Additionally, gains +2 for any seduction attempt against susceptible NPCs.

@graph.name: Blade Alignment
@graph.description: Increases the RES of blade weapon strikes, that is, with PEN = 1x, by 5xDM.

@graph.name: Blind Combat
@graph.description: Becomes immune to blindness against targets within the range of synesthesia and does not receive any penalty for using a closed helmet while synesthesia is active.

@graph.name: Blood Magic
@graph.description: Spends 1 AP to receive 1 light wound in exchange for health/2 STA.

@graph.name: Body Sculpting
@graph.description: Changes the shape of your body, reallocating one point from the natural component of AGI to STR every 4 hours and vice versa. Abilities that have STR or AGI requirements that are not met are disabled. It is necessary for the amount of flesh for any weight increase to be available.

@graph.name: Boogeyman
@graph.description: If an enemy is afraid, they will have to defend against the overwhelming terror spell when performing any offensive action against the caster.

@graph.name: Cadenced Shot
@graph.description: Normal shots and precise shots can exchange the STA cost for AP.

@graph.name: Caixão de Areia
@graph.description: Attempts to cover a creature of size 4 or smaller with sand. The sand follows and grabs the target, paralyzing and suffocating for 1 turn if they fail or scratch their Strength or Evasion defense. The effect is reapplied each turn until the duration ends. Requires large amounts of sand.

@graph.name: Call Lightning
@graph.description: Summons a lightning bolt to a specific target within the electrical storm as a directed effect. The lightning causes 25xDM electric damage. There is no distance penalty.

@graph.name: Call Wave
@graph.description: Pulls a wave from a body of water. It hits all who remain in the area and attempts to pull them into the water with a pulling action using the spell's DC instead of the character's Strength.

@graph.name: Calm
@graph.description: A spiritual attack that removes fear or rage if they fail or graze on a will test against the Enchantment.

@graph.name: Cell Reconstruction I/II
@graph.description: I. Spends 1 STA to accelerate the effect of a healing potion by an amount equal to health healed during rest. Stops deadly wounds. II. Reduces the cost by 1 AP.

@graph.name: Center of Attention
